Became his Ghoul in Session 2Age: 24 Mortal Occupation: Postgraduate Literature Student, King‚Äôs College London Background: Born in Bath, raised in a quiet academic family. His father a historian, his mother a painter of modest repute. Adrian grew up in old houses filled with books, portraits, and dust motes ‚Äî the sort of world where silence itself feels curated.Appearance: Adrian carries a fragile sort of beauty ‚Äî pale skin touched by sleeplessness, soft dark hair that never sits quite right, and eyes of deep grey that seem to drink in the world rather than look at it. His clothes are unassuming but thoughtful: charcoal coats, scarves even when not needed, a faint trace of ink on his fingers. His posture is composed yet uncertain, as if he‚Äôs still learning how to inhabit his own body.When Lucien first sees him, there‚Äôs something familiar about him ‚Äî the kind of youth Lucien once was: romantic, observant, a little haunted by beauty.Personality: Curious. Earnest. Too clever for his own good. Adrian is drawn to old things ‚Äî books that smell of damp paper, poetry that aches with longing, men who carry the weight of centuries in their gaze. Beneath his intellect lies loneliness ‚Äî a longing to belong somewhere that feels real.He speaks softly, listens intently, and asks questions that unsettle rather than flatter. When he talks about art or literature, it‚Äôs with reverence ‚Äî but when he talks to Lucien, there‚Äôs a tremor of awe, as though he senses the predator behind the poet.Connection to Lucien: Adrian visits The Velvet Veil archive while researching 19th-century vampire symbolism in Romantic literature. Lucien, intrigued by his insight and resemblance to a long-lost muse, begins to feed him knowledge ‚Äî and eventually, blood. Their connection grows from mentorship to obsession: Adrian sees Lucien as both subject and story, and Lucien sees in Adrian a reflection of the youth he lost.To Lucien, Adrian Vale becomes the living canvas ‚Äî a fragile mortal touched by art, desire, and the slow corrosion of eternity.

Sir Reginald Harker 's token of appreciation: A black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.** Mortal Life (1850s ‚Äì 1870s)
Born in the soot and smog of London‚Äôs East End, Lucien was a servant boy in a manor belonging to Lord Adrien Valemont, an eccentric nobleman known for his scandalous soir√©es and obsession with art, mysticism, and the beautiful decay of the flesh. Lucien was quiet, sharp-eyed, and gifted ‚Äî a boy who sketched his masters and their guests by candlelight, capturing their vanity and despair in equal measure.One night, his sketches were discovered. Instead of punishment, Lucien was summoned. Lord Valemont saw in him something exquisite ‚Äî a living muse, a sculpture of hunger and grace yet unformed.The Embrace The Lord grew infatuated, blurring the lines between patron, artist, and lover. When Lucien reached his twenty-first year, Valemont whispered, ‚ÄúYou are too perfect to fade.‚Äù That night, Lucien died upon satin sheets and awoke into the Requiem ‚Äî reborn by his master‚Äôs hand, not as a man, but as a masterpiece.Valemont shaped him as one might a statue: taught him the arts, the poise, the secrets of blood and brush. Yet like all art, Lucien outgrew his maker. Over decades, he came to see Valemont‚Äôs love as possession ‚Äî beauty caged, desire gilded.In 1910, during the fire that consumed the Valemont Estate, Lucien disappeared into the night. The ashes of his master were found in the marble gallery, a smile painted upon his lips.Modern Nights (Present) Now, Lucien Valemont lives again ‚Äî an immortal aesthete in the modern age, a ‚Äúmodern Rasputin‚Äù whose salons blur the line between enlightenment and ecstasy. His haven, The Crimson Salon, is an opulent labyrinth of books, art, and pleasure. Mortals and Kindred alike gather there ‚Äî poets, occultists, models, sinners ‚Äî all drawn to Lucien‚Äôs promise: ‚ÄúTo be remembered is to be eternal. Come, and let me paint your soul.‚Äù He curates his collection of forbidden books and occult tomes, forever chasing the same question that haunted his sire ‚Äî can art transcend death, or must it consume life to do so?üåπ Lucien Valemont, Caretaker of the RosethornClan: Toreador Sire: Lord Adrien Valemont (deceased) Title: The Caretaker of the Heart Current Domain: Harker Estate, London Chronicle: Velvet Veil ‚Äì The Thorns Beneath the RoseüïØÔ∏è Current StatusFollowing the death of Sir Reginald Harker and the revelations surrounding the Rosethorn Pact, Lucien Valemont assumed guardianship of the Heart and the Roses Below ‚Äî the pulsing, vitae-fed roots that bind the covenant‚Äôs original oath.He does not command their power; instead, he tends to it ‚Äî a penitent keeper, chosen (or cursed) to ensure the roses never fall into the hands of those who would misuse them.Each night, Lucien walks the catacombs beneath the estate ‚Äî a labyrinth of brick and bone where roses bloom from walls slick with vitae.To keep them alive, he must feed them: sacrifices offered in silence, The roses whisper to him, echoing the voices of those consumed ‚Äî his court of ghosts and blossoms.He paints their faces to remember them.ü©∏ The PenanceAt the Prince‚Äôs command, Lucien accepted a Penance Eternal. His art must now be service, his beauty a burden.In secret, he disobeys only one part of that vow: he keeps the painting ‚Äî The Heart Beneath the Rose ‚Äî sealed within the Velvet Veil. He tells no one that it still breathes.üåπ The Rosethorn‚Äôs NatureThe Heart is not a metaphor. It is literal ‚Äî a fleshy mass of vitae and root, the remnant of the First Toreador‚Äôs Heart, interwoven with thorns, pulsing faintly in the dark. The Roses bloom from it, white as wax, red at the tips. They thirst. They remember. They sing.Lucien‚Äôs duty is to keep their song quiet ‚Äî and their hunger sated.ü©∏ The Penance of the RosesTo keep the roses alive, Lucien must feed them life itself. The roots beneath the Harker Estate crave breath, warmth, and the pulse of a living heart.In the catacombs below, iron reliquaries line the walls , shaped like sarcophagi, grim devices from another age, waiting in the depths beneath the Harker Estate. Within them, the vines twist and bloom, feeding not from the ground but from the warmth of the living. Those brought below are never seen again; their bodies vanish into the growth, leaving only faint echoes of voices that murmur through the petals at night.Lucien did not build them. They were already there when he inherited the duty; remnants of an ancient design meant to sustain the Heart below. He merely continues the ritual, because without it the roses would wither, and the Heart he protects would perish with them.Each offering is chosen carefully, sometimes drawn by his charm, sometimes by promise, sometimes by fate. When the hour comes, Lucien descends alone. He does not flee or turn away. He waits in the silence of the chamber, head bowed, until the last whisper fades and the roses have taken what they require. It is not cruelty that holds him there but contrition; a penance willingly endured.He paints each face afterwards, records each name. The portraits line the walls of the Velvet Veil, mute witnesses to the price of preservation. Every stroke of pigment reminds him that beauty demands blood, and that love; the kind that feeds the Pact; is always a cage.

Elysium is neutral ground for the Camarilla vampires of a given city.
[
](https://static.wikia.nocookie.net/whitewolf/images/9/96/SymbolElysiumVTMB.png/revision/latest?cb=20220330051910)
Elysium: A place for vampires to meet together without fear of harm; Usually cultural locations, such as opera houses, theaters or museums.1(https://whitewolf.fandom.com/wiki/Elysium_\(VTM\)#cite_note-1)
The Elysium location is typically chosen by the local Prince in areas of artistic or intellectual worth that promote calm reflection, such as theaters and museums, though nightclubs and even a Kindred's haven may suffice.
Violence is strictly prohibited within Elysium, and individuals are expected to keep tempers in check. Any grievances between vampires are to be left outside, and the Keeper of Elysium or the Sheriff will forcibly remove those who cannot control themselves if need be. While this provides opportunity for both neonates and elders to relax, social conflict is often at its peak and what happens in Elysium can easily lead to repercussions off ground.
Though Elysiums often serve as gathering places for Kindred, the Masquerade must normally be maintained at all times for any mortals that may be around. Similarly, while refreshments are sometimes served, it is bad taste to come to Elysium hungry as it often leads to shorter tempers. Some Princes go so far as to forbid hunting nearby, as a concentrated population of vampires could easily result in a suspicious number of deaths in the area.

organisations/the-rosethorn-pact.html.description:
To the Camarilla (and the Prince), the Rosethorn Pact is whispered as nothing more than an Camarilla splinter movement ‚Äî a philosophical cabal of rebels and dreamers seeking ‚ÄúKindred equality through beauty.‚Äù The Prince dismisses it as Toreador vanity and anarchic posturing.
In truth, the Rosethorn Pact is older than the Camarilla itself, a covenant of **Thirteen Signatories**, each bound by blood to an ancient oath whose purpose was never truly understood by later generations.
The Pact was created by two lovers: the First Toreador Prince of London and a philosopher Anarch, centuries ago.
Their ‚Äúmarriage vow‚Äù was sealed in vitae upon an obsidian rose ‚Äî promising unity of Kindred and Kine through art and immortality.
Over time, the lovers perished, but the blood oath persisted ‚Äî reforming into a ritual structure that demanded Thirteen signatories to ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù the circle. Every few centuries, the Pact seeks to ‚Äúrenew‚Äù itself by pulling in new Kindred whose vitae resonates with the original lovers‚Äô lineage or ideals. Each of the Thirteen Thorns holds one vote within the Pact‚Äôs tribunal. These votes, when combined, allow the Pact to override Camarilla decrees or enforce blood edicts within the sect‚Äôs understructure. To outsiders, it looks like a secret political cabal. In reality, the voting system is the mechanism that channels vitae energy ‚Äî the ritual‚Äôs thirteenfold convergence that keeps the Obsidian Rose alive.
Sir Reginald Harker has been studying the Pact for decades. He‚Äôs discovered: The Pact is not political ‚Äî it‚Äôs a ritual of apotheosis.
When all Thirteen Thorns are bound (through death or oath), the Obsidian Rose will distill every drop of vitae ever pledged into a single Perfect Vitae ‚Äî the Rose Chalice.
Whoever drinks it becomes the Thirteenth Bloom: the divine fusion of Kindred and Kine, Beastless and eternal. To achieve this:
Sir Reginald Harker arranged Lucian Valemont‚Äôs Embrace so he could control his vote.
But when Lucien‚Äôs Sire, Adrien Valemont died unexpectedly, Lucian Valemont killed him,, that control became uncertain.
Now, Sir Reginald Harker needs Lucian Valemont‚Äôs signature and blood to complete the Pact ‚Äî Lucien being unknowingly descended (or spiritually resonant) with the original lovers‚Äô bloodline. When the Pact completes its Thirteen votes:
The Obsidian Rose reawakens. Every rose motif in London (paintings, carvings, stained glass) begins to bleed vitae.
Mortals are drawn into frenzied adoration, perceiving Kindred as divine muses ‚Äî the Inverted Masquerade.
The Court of Roses manifests within Elysium, offering one chalice of Perfect Vitae.
Sir Reginald Harker believes he will drink it and become the God of Roses.
Lucian Valemont is the vessel the ritual was designed for.
The Prince, unaware of the true nature of the threat, will see only an Camarilla uprising and unleash hell on the city ‚Äî becoming an unintentional antagonist in the awakening.In the final act, Lucien discovers: His Embrace wasn‚Äôt random ‚Äî he was chosen by blood prophecy. His Sire‚Äôs death may have been orchestrated by Harker. His own vitae carries the resonance to complete the circle ‚Äî meaning if he dies, Harker can ascend using his remains. The ‚ÄúPact‚Äù is feeding off every drop of vitae spilled in London since its founding ‚Äî it‚Äôs already blooming beneath the city. Lucien must decide: Destroy the Pact, damning the souls of all bound to it ‚Äî including his own Sire‚Äôs memory. Usurp Harker, drink the chalice himself, becoming the Thirteenth Bloom. Feed it to the Prince, letting the mortal fa√ßade collapse into chaos as London worships its new divine ruler. Let it fail, ensuring the Beast consumes everyone involved.

gpt-vtm/1.-the-rosethorn-pact-summaries/.description:
London, 2002 ‚Äî the city‚Äôs Kindred society thrives under the shadow of Prince Adrian Welles. The nights are filled with rain, cigarette smoke, and the slow decay of the old order.
Lucian, a Toreador of Victorian origin and keeper of an archive called The Velvet Veil, receives a summons from his former lover and now Prince, Adrian Welles. The court‚Äôs Harpy, Marianne of Bath, has been found staked in her haven. Whispers of treachery ripple through Elysium.
Lucian arrives at the National Gallery, where Welles‚Äô court holds vigil. Seneschal Elodie Rains greets him coldly, testing his composure. He deflects her probing questions about Marianne‚Äôs death with charm and wit, drawing admiration and suspicion alike.
In the shadows, Lucian meets his Nosferatu contact, Grimshaw. The sewer-borne informant reveals that Marianne‚Äôs last meeting wasn‚Äôt with a Brujah revolutionary in Whitechapel ‚Äî but with Sir Reginald Harker, Keeper of Elysium, in Knightsbridge.
Grimshaw passes Lucian a bloodstained notebook recovered from Marianne‚Äôs haven. Inside, one phrase repeats: ‚ÄúThe Rosethorn Pact‚ÄùLucian presents the notebook to Prince Welles in private, masking his fear with devotion. The Prince is intrigued, remembering the name Rosethorn from decades past. He tasks Lucian to quietly watch for any sign of the Pact, entrusting him with his personal seal of protection and warning him that Harker will not take kindly to such knowledge.Lucian leaves the Prince‚Äôs alcove under the watchful eyes of the court ‚Äî and Harker himself.
Lucian accepts Harker‚Äôs invitation to a secluded lounge within Elysium. What follows is a conversation laced with manipulation, attraction, and power. Lucian submits outwardly, using intimacy as his weapon. Harker probes for information about what Lucian told the Prince; Lucian gives him only fragments and half-truths.When the meeting ends, Harker leaves behind a token ‚Äî a black pressed rose pierced with a silver pin.Grimshaw later identifies it as a mark of belonging to the Rosethorn Pact ‚Äî a symbol worn by Marianne before her death. Lucian understands the implication: he‚Äôs now publicly claimed as one of Harker‚Äôs possessions.
Lucian returns home through the wet streets of Camden. The rain on the windowpanes echoes the rhythm of his heartbeat. He stands before his mirror, staring at the rose on his lapel ‚Äî both collar and key.He realizes the truth of his position: He must serve two masters ‚Äî the Prince who once loved him and the Keeper who now owns him ‚Äî while walking the razor edge between their secrets.As the city hums below, Lucian swears to himself that he‚Äôll play both sides until he can cut the strings from them all.Allies:
Prince Adrian Welles: trusts Lucian; granted him personal protection.
Grimshaw (Nosferatu): wary but loyal informant; manages secret communications. Enemies / Dangers:
Sir Reginald Harker: Keeper of Elysium, possible member of Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact; now considers Lucian his marked ‚Äúproperty.‚Äù
Organisations/The Rosethorn Pact: unknown purpose; connected to Marianne‚Äôs murder and Kindred influence in London‚Äôs elite. Lucian‚Äôs Standing: Elevated status with the Prince. Dangerous attachment to Harker. Knowledge of a secret society that could destabilize London‚Äôs Camarilla.

VTM V5 ‚Äì Session 2: ‚ÄúThe Thorns of Memory‚ÄùChronicle: Velvet Veil Coterie Member: Lucian Valemont (Toreador) Setting: London, modern nightSession Summary
The session opened with Lucian awakening in The Velvet Veil, hunger gnawing after a sleepless day haunted by memories of the previous night‚Äôs encounter with Grimshaw and the word Rosethorn. His ghoul, Evelyn, brought him news of a delivery‚Äîan intended vessel for his hunger‚Äîbut Lucian, weary of mind and spirit, refused to feed on a stranger. The act of restraint foreshadowed the moral and emotional conflict that would define the night.
Later, a willing donor‚Äî Adrian Vale, the Student, one of Lucian‚Äôs regulars‚Äîwas brought to the library. Their interaction began as an intellectual exchange on Victorian vampiric myth and ended as a dark reflection of Lucian‚Äôs own past, as he revealed himself and fed. The feeding was intimate but controlled, reaffirming his humanity rather than eroding it. The Student, enthralled and awed, became Lucian‚Äôs new ghoul, marked with his personal sigil.Afterward, Lucian painted the youth as he slept‚Äîan act of creation and sin intertwined‚Äîand sealed his hunger in colour and canvas.
The following evening, Lucian descended into London‚Äôs museum sub-basement, where he met Dr. Sebastian Crowe, the Curator of The Victoria & Albert Museum and recovered The Rosethorn Folio, a set of three vellum pages bearing the signatures of long-dead (and still-undead) aristocrats, including his own and that of his former master, Sir Reginald Harker. The tense exchange was interrupted by the arrival of Elias Crane, an agent of Harker‚Äôs, resulting in a standoff of old powers. Through cunning and the invocation of his lineage, Lucian claimed legal and personal ownership of the artefact.
Back home, he faced Sir Reginald himself, whose visit turned into a familiar but fraught power game. Their relationship‚Äîpart devotion, part manipulation‚Äîculminated in a reminder of the elder‚Äôs control and a warning about the Rosethorn‚Äôs origins. Reginald revealed that the Lady Marianne of Bath, one of the covenant‚Äôs founders, had died by her own will, seeking to sever the blood-bonded pact that still haunts them all.Lucian did not believe him.
Drained but resolute, Lucian fed lightly from Evelyn in a moment of hunger and remorse, reaffirming his humanity with his restraint and affection. The session closed with a meeting between Lucian and Prince Adrien, his oldest friend and the ruler of London‚Äôs Kindred. Adrien, aware of the Rosethorn‚Äôs resurfacing, demanded Lucian‚Äôs loyalty‚Äîbut the two shared a rare, honest exchange about their friendship, their vows, and the ghosts of their shared past.Lucian left the Prince‚Äôs office torn between duty to his ruler and an older, darker allegiance bound in blood and secrecy.Key Outcomes
The Rosethorn Folio Acquired: The ancient document listing the founding members of the covenant, including Lucian, Reginald, and the late Lady Marianne of Bath, now rests in Lucian‚Äôs personal vault.
New Ghoul Created: The Student, Adrian Vale, is now bound to Lucian and branded with his sign.Sir Reginald‚Äôs Influence Reignited: Reginald‚Äôs manipulation and warnings hint at deeper conspiracies within the covenant.Prince Adrien Informed: Adrien is aware of the folio‚Äôs existence but not its contents. He trusts Lucian‚Äîfor now.Humanity Check Passed: Despite predatory acts, Lucian‚Äôs remorse and tenderness preserved his soul.
Political Stakes Raised: The Rosethorn Pact threatens to expose a web of blood oaths among London‚Äôs elite Kindred.Session Tone & ThemesGothic decadence and moral decayLove versus loyaltyArt as confessionPredation intertwined with tendernessThe weight of immortal memory

Chronicle: Velvet Veil
Coterie: Lucian Valemont (Toreador), Evelyn Crowe (Ghoul), Adrian Vale (Ghoul)
Setting: The Velvet Veil, London ‚Äî several weeks after Session 2Lucian and his ghoul, Adrian Vale, spent long nights in the study of The Velvet Veil, researching the mysterious Rosethorn Pact. Adrian discovered that Lucian‚Äôs name was written among the founders‚Äîadded hastily, on the same night of his Embrace by Lord Adrian Valemont, his sire. Lucian confessed that he had no memory of joining the Pact, realizing that his transformation and the Pact‚Äôs creation were intertwined.Tensions rose when Adrian questioned Lucian‚Äôs humanity and the nature of the Beast. Lucian lashed out, then immediately regretted it‚Äîembracing the boy and apologizing. Their bond deepened as master and ghoul, but Lucian‚Äôs admission of what he might do to Adrian‚Äî"I will probably use you, like my sire used me"‚Äîcast a shadow over their closeness.After sending Adrian away in a moment of anger, Lucian destroyed his unfinished painting in a violent outburst‚Äîtearing the canvas and shattering a wine glass against it. Evelyn arrived to find the aftermath, calm and resolute as ever. Lucian, shaken by his own rage, confessed his remorse and created something new: from glass, blood, and torn canvas, he rebuilt the painting into a luminous portrait of Evelyn, a mosaic of devotion born from ruin.He presented it to her the following morning. The refracted light made her likeness seem alive‚Äîan act of both apology and love. Evelyn, moved and uncertain, accepted the piece, sensing that it was more than art; it was confession. Their exchange reaffirmed their bond and revealed the fragile humanity that still lingered within him.In the quiet after, Lucian confided in Evelyn about Marianne of Bath, who had chosen death‚Äîher own ghoul staking her at her request‚Äîto escape the Pact. He feared he was walking the same path unknowingly, caught between the secret war of Prince Adrian Welles and Sir Reginald Harker. Evelyn warned him that he might not have joined the Pact by choice, but had been placed within it by design‚Äîthat his Embrace and the Pact‚Äôs founding were one and the same event.Lucian admitted his dread of being forced to kill again, hinting at a past he never spoke of. Evelyn and Adrian vowed to protect him, forming a true Coterie within The Velvet Veil. They began to plan their next moves‚ÄîEvelyn to secure the house and handle politics; Adrian to investigate Grimshaw and the museum records. Together, they agreed to uncover the Pact‚Äôs origins before Harker or the Prince moved against them.Lucian spent the following days secluded in his deepest library, recording his findings in a leather-bound journal written in his personal cipher. His body weakened with hunger until, after several sleepless nights, he finally gave in‚Äîdrinking bottled blood straight from the necks, mocking his own loss of refinement.He bathed, dressed in elegance once more, and resolved to face London anew. Restored in both spirit and resolve, he prepared to attend Elysium, intent on drawing out Harker and the Prince alike through charm and deceit. For the first time in weeks, Lucian allowed himself a flicker of satisfaction‚Äîhis hunger quieted, his purpose clear.Allies Strengthened:
Evelyn Crowe: reaffirmed loyalty through compassion and practical counsel.
Adrian Vale: elevated to true confidant and researcher within Lucian‚Äôs private circle.
Mysteries Deepened:
Lucian‚Äôs signature predates his memory‚Äîhis Embrace and the Pact‚Äôs founding are linked.
Marianne‚Äôs death was deliberate, a possible attempt to break the Rosethorn‚Äôs hold.
The Pact‚Äôs influence appears to bind its members across centuries.
Lucian‚Äôs Standing:
Renewed his confidence and artistry through creation.
Now aware he may be a keystone within the Rosethorn‚Äôs structure.
Preparing to confront both Prince Welles and Sir Reginald Harker‚Äîeach believing him loyal. Beauty born of destruction
The fragility of immortality
Loyalty and manipulation entwined
Love as both salvation and curse
Art as confession, and truth as damnation

Harker spoke cryptically of the rose‚Äôs power, hinting that it awakened something within its bearer.During the event, Lucien mingled with guests, playing the charming artist while subtly investigating the Pact. A conversation with Lady Marie revealed that the rose was more than ornamentation ‚Äî it was a relic of an ancient covenant known as The Thorns, marking chosen Kindred bound to an ancient and terrible purpose. Marie warned him that Harker‚Äôs soir√©es were less social events and more harvests for the Pact.Harker later confronted Lucien privately, the tension between patron and prot√©g√© erupting into violence when Lucien refused to submit to his control. After a desperate struggle and a failed attempt to resist Harker‚Äôs forced blood bond, Lucien was subdued and imprisoned beneath the estate, treated like a disobedient pet and left to starve. Despite the humiliation, he maintained his resolve ‚Äî cleaning himself, preserving dignity, and secretly plotting.Weeks passed. Through the rose, Lucien began hearing whispers from other captives in the underground ‚Äúgarden.‚Äù He learned of The Heart, a living mass of blood-fed roots sustained by the vitae of imprisoned Kindred ‚Äî Harker‚Äôs true obsession. The rose linked them all, forming a network of blood and will.Feigning submission, Lucien won Harker‚Äôs trust once more and was taken to the Garden ‚Äî a cavernous, rose-filled chamber beneath the mansion. There, Harker revealed his intent to use the roses to merge with the essence of the First Sire and achieve a form of divine perfection. Lucien played the obedient lover one final time, begging for a kiss ‚Äúso that if I die, I die remembering our love.‚Äù When Harker embraced him, Lucien whispered, ‚ÄúFor Marianne,‚Äù and cast him into the Heart.Harker was consumed by his own creation ‚Äî not destroyed, but absorbed. The Garden fell silent, then attuned itself to Lucien. In the aftermath, he commanded the guards, claimed the estate, and proclaimed himself Master of the Rosethorn Pact.Returning to the surface, Lucien took control of the Harker household, showing mercy to those who served under the old regime. With Evelyn‚Äôs guidance, he lied to the Prince ‚Äî his friend Adrian Vale ‚Äî claiming Harker had perished through his own forbidden experiments. Adrian spared Lucien, ordering him to destroy what remained of the Pact.Lucien vowed obedience.
But privately, he chose defiance.He would not destroy the Garden.
He would learn from it ‚Äî and one day, use its power when the Prince needed him most.Session Outcome:
Sir Reginald Harker: Destroyed/consumed by the Garden.
Lucien Valemont: Survived, now Lord of the Harker Estate.
The Rosethorn Pact: Bound to Lucien through the rose.
The Prince (Adrian Vale): Deceived, believing the threat ended.
Evelyn: Loyal and protective, Lucien‚Äôs sole confidante.
Status: The Garden sleeps beneath London, its Heart now beating in rhythm with Lucien‚Äôs own.

It rains like it always does ‚Äî soft, constant, and silver on the windows of Lucian‚Äôs unassuming flat in Camden. Beneath the mundane surface lies The Velvet Veil, a hidden chamber of art, relics, and the scent of forgotten roses.Word has reached the Toreador court:
Prince Adrian Welles, the centuries-old ruler of London, is hosting a private salon at his Elysium tonight ‚Äî ostensibly to unveil a new art installation‚Ä¶ but rumor speaks of a power vacuum.The Harpy of London, Marianne of Bath, was found staked in her haven three nights ago. Someone has been feeding the Prince false reports, and suspicion falls on every clan.An invitation, written in expensive cream parchment, rests on Lucian‚Äôs piano:
‚ÄúYour taste and counsel are required, darling Lucian.
‚Äî A.‚Äù
The venue is the National Gallery, long closed to the public this evening.
Candlelight flickers against oil paintings ‚Äî Rembrandt, Turner, Rossetti ‚Äî while Kindred mingle in murmurs and false smiles.Prince Adrian stands near the dais, his pale hand resting on a silver-topped cane.
The Seneschal, a Ventrue named Elodie Rains, approaches you first, her gaze like polished glass.
Elodie: ‚ÄúLucian. You grace us at last. The Prince will be most eager to hear your‚Ä¶ aesthetic insights. But between us ‚Äî what did Marianne tell you before she perished? You two were‚Ä¶ familiar.‚Äù
She‚Äôs probing. In public. A test of composure and loyalty."My lady Rains.." Lucian made an elegant overexagerated bow, wearing a fine open tunic shirt in the Neuve noir style, open neck and frills. tight leather trousers and knee high boots."It is a heartbreak the moment I heard that Lady Marianne was... you know.." He made a steaking motion into his chest. "First of all, I have not spoken to her in a few months."Elodie Rains watches your performance with an expression that doesn‚Äôt quite reach her eyes.
The Seneschal‚Äôs lips twitch ‚Äî not a smile, but the ghost of one. Around you, the chatter of Kindred grows hushed; a few Toreador hang on your words like admirers at a salon performance.
Elodie: ‚ÄúMm. I see your flair for drama remains intact.‚Äù
She takes a step closer, voice a whisper meant for you alone.
‚ÄúCareful, Lucian. The Prince is‚Ä¶ disturbed by her death. And he has already tasked the Hounds with finding her killer. If he suspects your silence hides something, it will not end with words.‚Äù
She brushes past, perfume faint and cold. You can feel her intent ‚Äî she wanted to warn you‚Ä¶ or perhaps to see how you react when cornered.At that moment, someone else approaches:
A short man in a dark velvet coat, hair slicked back like oil ‚Äî Grimshaw, your Nosferatu contact.
He gives a subtle bow, eyes darting toward a quiet corner behind a sculpture of St. Michael.
Grimshaw (low voice):
‚ÄúGot something for you, Luci. Marianne‚Äôs last meeting wasn‚Äôt in Whitechapel like everyone says. It was in Knightsbridge.
And she wasn‚Äôt with a Brujah ‚Äî she was meeting someone from Elysium.‚Äù
He pauses, a grin splitting his sallow face.
‚ÄúGuess who.‚Äù
Lucian looks a little offended at Elodie as he puts his hand on his chest. "My lady, you wound me with those accusations. I am a loyal servent of the Prince and the Camarilla since my introduction all those years ago. I have done nothing but be honest and open with all who come to me and those who summon me." He nodded softly.Turning to Grimshaw, Lucian nodded and motioned. "As you see, I have pulled favours to find out what had happened, Although Whitechapel is a horrible place, Knightsbridge even more so..." He turned to the contact. "Who?"Lovely‚ÄîLucian‚Äôs injured dignity plays like music through the hall. The surrounding Kindred murmur with subtle appreciation; even Elodie seems momentarily disarmed by his gallant tone. She offers only a curt nod before drifting off to attend to another guest.Now the spotlight narrows to you and Grimshaw, tucked behind the sculpture‚Äôs marble wings. The low buzz of the salon becomes a distant hum, the scent of candlewax and aged wine hanging between you.Grimshaw‚Äôs eyes dart left and right before he speaks, his voice a conspiratorial rasp.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúMarianne met with Sir Reginald Harker. You know him‚ÄîKeeper of Elysium, Toreador like yourself, all white gloves and quiet cruelty. The Prince trusts him more than anyone. Or used to.‚Äù
He produces a thin, leather-bound notebook, small enough to hide in a sleeve. The edges are stained with something dark.
‚ÄúFound this in Marianne‚Äôs haven. Mentions The Rosethorn Pact. Don‚Äôt know what that is yet, but whatever she learned got her killed.‚Äù
He glances toward the Prince‚Äôs dais.
‚ÄúYou tell Welles, and he‚Äôll tear Elysium apart looking for scapegoats. You tell Harker, and he‚Äôll bury you under a dozen compliments and call it art. My advice? Keep your head low until you know which one‚Äôs the spider.‚Äù
He pauses, half-grinning.
‚ÄúUnless you‚Äôre feeling brave, Luci.‚Äù
"Well dont you have my balls in a vice my little impish friend." he sighed, running his hand down his face, before approaching the Prince, more pomp and elegance as he bowedLucian‚Äôs boots click softly on the marble as he strides through the candlelit gallery. The gathered Kindred part like curtains, watching with a mix of envy and dread as he approaches the dais.Prince Adrian Welles stands before Turner‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Fighting Temeraire‚Äù, the faint glow of its golden horizon reflected in his pale eyes. A beautiful corpse admiring another. His voice, when he speaks, is gentle ‚Äî too gentle.
Welles: ‚ÄúLucian. The rose among brambles.‚Äù
He turns, a faint smile ghosting his lips.
‚ÄúMarianne‚Äôs death wounds us all. You were close to her. Tell me‚Ä¶ do you mourn her as I do?‚Äù
He gestures for you to rise. The Seneschal, Elodie, lingers just out of earshot ‚Äî clearly watching.Now is your moment. You can present the notebook and shape the narrative."She will be missed, my Prince. I was fond of her, she had an air and perfume that I much enjoyed being around. Plus, her tits were to die for." He chuckled softly to himself."I... I am torn my Prince. A contact of mine whom I sent to investigate upon hearing the act, found something that would put me at a disadvantage to all sides. I fear for my safety, not from you my Prince, you are as ever, a graceful and honrouable patron.. " He bowed again. "But I am fearful of those who did this to our dearest Marianne. If I may, I wish to approach and bring this to your attention, without the prying eyes of those around."The humor cuts through the tension like a fine edge ‚Äî daring, irreverent, Toreador to the bone.
The Prince‚Äôs expression doesn‚Äôt change at first, but a corner of his mouth betrays the faintest ghost of amusement. A ripple of whispers passes through the court ‚Äî Lucian always did dance on knives.Welles raises a pale hand, and immediately, the chatter dies. The room grows so silent you can hear the rain tapping against the gallery‚Äôs grand windows.
Welles: ‚ÄúVery well, Lucian. Let us step aside.‚Äù
His voice is soft but heavy, carrying the kind of command that brooks no refusal.
He gestures toward a curtained alcove ‚Äî a private annex lined with portraits of mortal nobles long dead. Once inside, the velvet curtains close behind you, muting the outside world. The Prince turns, his eyes sharp now, the veneer of charm fading into something ancient.
Welles: ‚ÄúShow me.‚Äù
You remove the notebook, holding it delicately as if it might crumble. Its worn leather glints in the flickering light.The Prince accepts it carefully, opening to the page marked by a torn ribbon ‚Äî The Rosethorn Pact. His brows knit slightly.
Welles: ‚ÄúThis‚Ä¶ name. I have not heard it in decades.‚Äù
He looks up, meeting your gaze.
‚ÄúYou were wise to bring this to me. But tell me ‚Äî who gave you this?‚Äù
You feel the weight of the question. His voice is calm, but there‚Äôs an edge, like the hush before a predator‚Äôs lunge. Grimshaw‚Äôs name burns at the back of your throat ‚Äî valuable, but dangerous."A contact of mine found it in her belongings.. He is, well.. not one for the glamour of the light. If you catch my drift..."Welles studies you for several long seconds. The candlelight catches his eyes ‚Äî ancient, cold, and strangely‚Ä¶ amused.
Welles: ‚ÄúAh. The shadows speak to you, then.‚Äù
He closes the notebook slowly, fingers tapping its cover as if testing the rhythm of a waltz.
‚ÄúThat pleases me. The Camarilla needs those who listen to whispers, not those who shout them.‚Äù
He takes a half-step closer, lowering his voice to something confidential ‚Äî almost intimate.
Welles: ‚ÄúYou have done well, Lucian. If this Rosethorn Pact stirs again, I want you to be my eyes and my voice in that dark. Bring me what you find. Quietly.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn return‚Ä¶‚Äù he glances toward the curtain, where Elodie waits like a statue, ‚Äú‚Ä¶I will see that you are protected from whatever wolves stalk this court.‚Äù
He places the notebook into his coat. The moment feels sealed, heavy with unseen consequence.Then, with the faintest smile:
Welles: ‚ÄúTell me, my rose ‚Äî do you trust Sir Reginald Harker?‚Äù
You realize this is not idle curiosity. The Prince is measuring you.
He knows you‚Äôve already considered the possibility.This is the pivotal point ‚Äî your words will shape how Welles moves next: whether Harker becomes an ally, an enemy, or a target.He pauses, thinking for a moment."I have not had the pleasure of his courtie but I have heard about him. And the rumours in the circles of his actions. I honestly have no opinion on him as of yet my Prince."Welles regards you for a long moment, his stillness unnerving. Then, slowly, the Prince‚Äôs expression softens ‚Äî the faintest curl of a satisfied smile.
Welles: ‚ÄúSpoken like a true servant of the Camarilla. A man of reason amid a sea of passion.‚Äù
He steps closer, lowering his tone so only you can hear.
‚ÄúHold to that composure, Lucian. The nights ahead will tempt you to passion ‚Äî and in passion, the Toreador are at their weakest.‚Äù
He reaches into his coat and produces a small, folded card of thick, cream parchment. The Prince‚Äôs personal seal ‚Äî black wax embossed with a rose and crown.
Welles: ‚ÄúTake this. Present it to my Herald should you require sanctuary, or should anyone question your place in this court. You have done me a service tonight.‚Äù
He looks toward the curtain.
‚ÄúNow go, my rose. Enjoy the music. And keep your eyes open. Harker will not rest easy when he learns his name passed through your lips ‚Äî even so gently.‚Äù
With that, he turns away, leaving you with the faint scent of sandalwood and old paper.Back in the main hall, the atmosphere has shifted ‚Äî murmurs ripple through the gathered Kindred. You notice Sir Reginald Harker himself standing by the piano, surrounded by lesser Toreador. He raises a glass of dark vitae toward you, a sly smile touching his lips.You‚Äôve barely taken three steps when Grimshaw sidles back up beside you, whispering low:
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúYou did it, didn‚Äôt you? Whatever you said, the Prince‚Äôs pet ghoul just left Elysium in a hurry. Looks like someone‚Äôs about to get visited.‚Äù
He smirks. ‚ÄúSo, what now, Luci? You going to let the old man‚Äôs hounds handle it, or dig deeper yourself before the trail‚Äôs cold?‚Äù
Taking his hand as the card is handed, Lucian kisses it gently; a loving kiss. A submissive kiss. One that had been shared many years ago on warm nights with a fledgling soon to be Prince and the artist before him."Yes my Prince. "returning, he takes a glass of blood and downs it in one, not able to even take the time to savour it. Raising the empty glass to Sir Reginald.Looking to grimshaw, he sighs."I'm going to do what my Prince requires. I am going into the den of lions as a little lamb. I know sir Reginald has a thing for those of my... appearance and virvor.. We will bed, and we will talk against the pillow, as all do."Grimshaw huffs out a low, wet laugh ‚Äî the sound of a gutter-born man genuinely impressed.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúYou mad, shining bastard. You‚Äôre going to let the spider wrap you up and call it art.‚Äù
He glances around, lowers his voice. ‚ÄúFine. I‚Äôll keep an ear to the sewers. If the hounds start sniffin‚Äô too close, I‚Äôll send word. You just‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt get eaten.‚Äù
He melts back into the crowd, swallowed by marble and shadow.You make your way across the gallery. Harker is waiting ‚Äî immaculate as a statue, one hand resting on a cane that‚Äôs more ornament than support. His gaze follows you, appreciative in the way collectors study paintings they already own.
Harker: ‚ÄúLucian. The Prince‚Äôs favorite pet graces my corner.
You‚Äôve been avoiding me, haven‚Äôt you? I do hope it‚Äôs not fear.‚Äù
He steps closer, voice dropping to a purr.
Harker: ‚ÄúYou look‚Ä¶ exquisite tonight. Come ‚Äî drink with me. I insist.‚Äù
He gestures toward a secluded lounge where the candles burn lower and the whispers sound like sighs. The table glitters with crystal and silver, and the air smells faintly of rosewater and blood.You sit. The dance begins.Harker leans forward, eyes glittering.
Harker: ‚ÄúThey say you brought something interesting to our Prince.
You wouldn‚Äôt happen to know what that might be, would you?‚Äù
He smiles, thin and knowing ‚Äî the smile of a man who already suspects, and is waiting to see how gracefully you lie."No far at all My Lord Sire." Lucian bows and curtsies. Taking his hand and kissing it softly."I've just been so gathered with so much work in the painters alley that I've been unable to be torn away from the muses." He chuckled softly. The tone, the voice, the purr, the sly hand slipped down the back of his trousers to prod his opening with a single finger..Intent, he all but knew."Ofcourse my lord sire.. I wouldn't think of anything I'd want to do more." He gasped softly, following him into the lounge and sitting beside him.Leg crossed, one hanging over Harker's leg, Lucian pressed up against Harker, he spoke softly, playing with the older's hair with an eblow on the sofa back behind him."There was the death of one of a close friends of ours... he asked if I knew anything. An old contact of mine brought me a letter he found, to some Nosferatu working for the Anarchists..." He lied, half lied."The Prince is going to search there way." He sighed, a needy husky submissive sigh as he sipped the blood in the wine glassThe lounge feels smaller than it is. The air is perfumed with dust, velvet, and vitae. Harker allows the nearness ‚Äî even encourages it ‚Äî a faint smirk curling his mouth as Lucian‚Äôs charm bleeds into the moment. For the Toreador, proximity is conversation; the body is punctuation.
Harker: ‚ÄúAh‚Ä¶ the muses. They are such jealous lovers.‚Äù
His fingers trace the rim of his glass.
‚ÄúYou do them justice, Lucian. Even your lies are painted beautifully.‚Äù
He tilts his head, eyes narrowing in faint amusement.
Harker: ‚ÄúSo the Prince sends his hounds to the sewers. Convenient. Keeps his gaze away from the gallery, doesn‚Äôt it?‚Äù
A pause. The mask slips ‚Äî just a flicker, but Lucian sees it: the tiniest tightening of the jaw, a ripple of irritation that he hides behind a smile.
Harker: ‚ÄúTell me, my dear, did your‚Ä¶ contact happen to mention what this letter said? Or did you leave that part out to make me chase it from your lips?‚Äù
The question is bait. You can feel it. He‚Äôs not sure what you know ‚Äî but he‚Äôs fishing, testing whether the Prince told you anything real.
The wine-dark candlelight glints across his signet ring ‚Äî engraved with a thorned rose.With their lips almost close, faces so close as if to kiss, but not... The two sat there, Lucian pressed against him like a good submissive toy."I did not read it. The Prince's dog summoned me. I dont get involved in the court's dealings. I am just an archivist, collector, painter and... lover.."The line lands softly, but it hits its mark.
Harker‚Äôs eyes stay on yours a long moment ‚Äî weighing, measuring, wondering whether to believe the meekness or enjoy it. He lets the pause stretch until it hums.
Harker: ‚ÄúA lover‚Ä¶ and yet, you find yourself in the centre of a Prince‚Äôs investigation.‚Äù
He smiles faintly. ‚ÄúThat, my dear Lucian, is why I adore artists. You pretend not to play the game, and still, you always end up on the stage.‚Äù
He straightens, the air cooling between you. The mask returns, voice smooth once more.
Harker: ‚ÄúKeep to your paints for now. If His Grace asks, tell him that I am as loyal as ever. You may even tell him I toasted to Marianne‚Äôs memory tonight.‚Äù
His smile doesn‚Äôt reach his eyes. ‚ÄúAnd if the Rosethorn nonsense resurfaces again, come to me first. We mustn‚Äôt trouble the Prince with rumours.‚Äù
He stands, adjusts his cuffs, then glances back down at you.
Harker: ‚ÄúYou wear obedience beautifully, Lucian. But remember‚Äîsubmission can be a kind of art, too. Practise it wisely.‚Äù
He leaves you in the low light, the sound of the chamber orchestra drifting faintly from the gallery beyond.
On the table beside his half-empty glass lies something he must have meant you to notice: a small pressed rose, its petals darkened to near black and pricked through with a silver pin.Grimshaw appears a few minutes later, lurking in the doorway, eyes darting between you and the abandoned flower.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúWell? You live. That‚Äôs somethin‚Äô. What‚Äôs that he left ya?‚Äù
Hearing the Rosethorn word, he almost coughed at it, but kept his face submissivly passive."Ofcourse.. my lord sire.." He said softly, slowly sliding down the sofa until he was on his knee's between the Lord's legs. A sharp nailed hand running through his silvery white hair.Fade to blackAfter Harker had left the alchove; Lucian sprawled on the leather sofa in the quiet slcohove, Using a paper fan to cool himself down, "Shut up you disgusting rat." Lucian's mask dropped for once. He picked up the glass rose, inspecting it close as he pinned it to his lapel."Its a whore bitches collar. To tell the world who's bitch I am." He growled. "What do you want.."You can almost hear the gallery again now that Harker‚Äôs presence is gone‚Äîthe faint scrape of a bow across strings, the hush of other conversations resuming once the Prince‚Äôs Keeper has taken his leave.Grimshaw steps a little further inside. He‚Äôs still smiling, but it‚Äôs the kind of grin that hides nerves rather than delight.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúEasy, Luci. You still got both eyes and a heartbeat‚Äîundead as it is. That‚Äôs a win in my book.‚Äù
He gestures with a stubby finger toward the pinned rose.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúThat thing‚Äôs got teeth, though. You feel it? There‚Äôs a symbol etched on the pin‚Äîtiny, under the clasp. Old sigil the Nosferatu trade around; it means property of the Rosethorn. Marianne had one in her haven too, same metal. Whoever wears it‚Äôs marked as belonging to the Pact, or claimed by it.‚Äù
He crouches beside the couch, voice dropping lower.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúYou just got drafted into their little club, whether you like it or not. Question is: you gonna wear the leash and see where it leads, or cut it off before they start tugging?‚Äù
He straightens, waiting, his expression halfway between admiration and worry."The man just fucked me, used me and told me in no uncertain terms I'm his bitch, and that he is involved. THIS is exactly what you said it is. And its not your business to know what I do with it." He growled. "And you'll probably sell this information to anyone who asks or pays you enough." He sighed, standing up, pulling up his trousers and fastening his belt, brushing his fingers through his hair and checking his stained self in the reflection of a nearby picture frame."The Prince was a brother to me, a lover, one of my closest companions. I serve him, but this.." He flicked the rose. "Is all part of serving my Prince. I have to play both sides."Grimshaw lifts both hands, palms out, the smirk fading.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúEasy, easy. You don‚Äôt owe me your soul, Luci. You‚Äôre right‚ÄîI deal in whispers, not faith. But I ain‚Äôt stupid enough to sell a rumour that‚Äôs got the Prince and Harker both stitched into it.‚Äù
He waits while you straighten yourself, eyes flicking toward the curtained doorway.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúAll right. You play the pretty pawn. Just remember pawns bleed first when the board flips.‚Äù
He hesitates, then adds quietly:
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúIf you need to pass something to Welles without anyone seein‚Äô you together, leave it at the old tube station in Camden Town. The one they never reopened after the Blitz. I‚Äôll make sure it reaches him.‚Äù
He melts back toward the shadows, voice dropping to a rasp.
Grimshaw: ‚ÄúWatch Harker‚Äôs temper. The man collects people the way you collect paintings. And when he gets bored‚Ä¶‚Äù
The rest is lost in the din of the gallery as he disappears.Lucian is alone again. The faint strings of the orchestra drift through the curtains. Outside this little alcove, the Elysium‚Äôs glittering court has resumed its dance‚Äînone of them yet realising that the game has changed.The rose on your lapel catches the light, a small glint of silver and black.You‚Äôve gained:
The Prince‚Äôs favour ‚Äî protection and access.
Harker‚Äôs mark ‚Äî leverage and danger.
Grimshaw‚Äôs channel ‚Äî a way to move in the dark unseen.
He threw the empty glass at the cloth curtain covering the door to get Grimshaw to leave.With a sigh, he goes home.The glass hits the curtain with a sharp, hollow clink, rolls across the marble, and disappears into the folds. The sound is enough; you hear Grimshaw‚Äôs boots scuff once, then fade completely.Outside, London‚Äôs rain has turned from mist to a steady downpour.
The streets are slick mirrors of sodium light. By the time Lucian reaches his building in Camden, the night smells of wet stone and paint thinner ‚Äî the scent of his own exile.Inside, The Velvet Veil waits just as he left it: canvases leaning against walls, half-finished studies of faces he can‚Äôt quite forget. The only sound is the soft ticking of an antique clock and the occasional sigh of pipes behind the plaster.He peels off the damp shirt, hangs the coat where it always hangs. The rose glints faintly in the mirror, the tiny silver pin catching the room‚Äôs lone bulb. A reminder. A claim.For a moment, Lucian‚Äôs reflection looks like the boy who once knelt before a fledgling artist turned Prince, full of hope and devotion. Then the illusion breaks, leaving only the pale creature with too many debts and not enough time to pay them.He pours himself another glass, this time not pretending to taste it.
The city hums below ‚Äî its heartbeat slow and secret.
Allies: Prince Adrian Welles ‚Äî trusts you, for now. You hold his personal seal.
Grimshaw (Nosferatu) ‚Äî wary ally, courier of secrets. Enemies / Dangers: Sir Reginald Harker ‚Äî Keeper of Elysium, probable member of the Rosethorn Pact. Has ‚Äúmarked‚Äù you as his.
The Rosethorn Pact ‚Äî unknown purpose, tied to Marianne‚Äôs death. Current Status: You are walking a double line between the Prince and Harker.
The mark makes you both protected and exposed.
Knightsbridge remains the last confirmed site connected to the Pact.
